metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Neurosurgery services in Dr. Sardjito General Hospital, Yogyakarta, Indonesia, during COVID-19 pandemic: an experience from a developing country Neurosurgery services in Dr. Sardjito General Hospital, Yogyakarta, Indonesia, during COVID-19 pandemic: an experience from a developing country

abstract.text: BACKGROUND Most articles describing the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on neurosurgical services have been from developed countries. We attempt to report our experience in carrying out neurosurgical services in Dr. Sardjito General Hospital, Yogyakarta, Indonesia, during the time of the pandemic. METHODS To collect information on the effect of the pandemic in Indonesia and Yogyakarta, we gathered data from the Indonesian Ministry of Health online database for the national data and local government records for the local data (including records of Dr. Sardjito General Hospital Division of Neurosurgery). RESULTS Compared to other countries, Indonesia has not been severely hit by the impact of COVID-19. To raise the understanding of the natural history of the pandemic, we grouped the period into four different phases: Phase 1 (there was confirmed cases in Indonesia but no cases found in Yogyakarta), Phase 2 (the first case in Yogyakarta detected), Phase 3 (the time when the cumulative cases surpass its peak), and Phase 4 (the pandemic ends). At the time of this writing, we were still in Phase 2 and in this phase, we experienced a decrease in the number of emergency surgical procedures, from an average of 4 to 2.4 procedures per week. Moreover, the number of elective operations dropped from an average of 12 to 9 procedures per week. CONCLUSIONS A pandemic, such as COVID-19, reduces both inpatient and outpatient neurosurgical activities. A comprehensive plan can improve both utilization and safety of the neurosurgical staff.

body_text.text: The COVID-19 case was first reported in Indonesia on March 2, 2020. 1 Since then, the number of people who are infected with SARS-CoV-2 has grown exponentially, a pattern that can usually be observed in an uninhibited outbreak. 2,3 Some experts stated that the number would continue to soar in the next few weeks if no significant intervention is given. 4 The government then announced a public health emergency on March 31, 2020. 5 Following the public health emergency announcement, the Indonesian government imposed a temporary ban on all foreign travelers and also published several other regulations. 6 One major regulation was a guideline for large-scale social restriction [PMK NO. 9 TH. 2020 (Pedoman Pembatasan Sosial Bersakala Besar (PSBB)]. The local governments with a high number of cases or deaths in their regions were allowed to impose such restriction with approval from the Indonesian Ministry of Health. 7 The application of such measure included banning mass gathering, closing schools and offices, curbing non-essential business, and banning public transport. 7 Furthermore, the Indonesian Ministry of Health had selected several hospitals as the referral hospitals to handle the emerging infectious disease (KH.01.07/MENKES/169/2020). Dr. Sardjito
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: General Hospital was one of the selected hospitals located in the Special Region of Yogyakarta. 8 The hospital, which is also the university hospital for Universitas Gadjah Mada, was chosen since it had a full-range intensive unit and possessed two isolation wards for airborne infectious disease. 9 Lastly, to accommodate more COVID-19 patients, the hospital also remodeled one ward as a new isolation ward.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Compared to other countries located outside the equatorial zone, the number of COVID-19 cases has been relatively small in Indonesia. 10 However, the outbreak is believed to add an extra burden to the health care system throughout the globe, including Indonesia. 11 Neurosurgical service is one of the systems affected. 12 Several articles have discussed how neurosurgical services should be managed during this difficult time. 13, 14 However, there is no specific report on how it runs in developing countries. This article focuses on neurosurgical service in Dr. Sardjito General Hospital, Yogyakarta, Indonesia, as a representative of low-and middle-income countries (LMIC). Moreover, while the number of COVID-19 cases has been rather low in Yogyakarta, we believe that hospital preparedness and contingency plan for a pandemic should be formulated, especially for neurosurgery cases, to manage the potential development of this pandemic and any other outbreak in the future.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We reviewed what has been done by related stakeholders to curb the impact of the disease.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To collect information on the effect of the outbreak in Indonesia, we looked into the COVID-19 online database created by the Indonesian Ministry of Health. The government had selected the
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: Kesehatan Kementerian Kesehatan (Balitbangkes)] as COVID-19 national referral laboratory. In addition, the government also selected several regional laboratories as the COVID-19 diagnostic laboratories 15 . All facilities had to meet the Bio-Safety Level 2 (BSL-2) standard and possessed reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) equipment. 16 By the middle of April 2020, the Indonesian government had tested more than 30,000 samples (i.e., about 130 tests per 1 million population). 17 Furthermore, we gathered information from COVID-19 online records generated by the Yogyakarta government to assess the effect of the outbreak in the Special Region of Yogyakarta.
body_text.section: National Institute of Health Research and Development [Badan Penelitian dan Pengembangan

body_text.text: By April 13, 2020, the Yogyakarta administration had performed 516 tests, which was about 144 tests per 1 million people. 18 The data about COVID-19 confirmed cases from all laboratories throughout Indonesia was then sent to Balitbangkes to be validated and verified. 15 All confirmed cases, which included inpatients, recovered patients, and deaths, had been confirmed using RT-PCR test. 15 Finally, it was sent to the Public Health Emergency Operation Center of the Indonesian Ministry of Health.
body_text.section: National Institute of Health Research and Development [Badan Penelitian dan Pengembangan

body_text.text: The data regarding the number of neurosurgical procedures that were done from February 2, 2020 to April 10, 2020 in Dr. Sardjito General Hospital was gathered from the record of Dr.
body_text.section: National Institute of Health Research and Development [Badan Penelitian dan Pengembangan

body_text.text: Sardjito General Hospital Division of Neurosurgery. Emergency cases were defined as head tumor and cerebrovascular problems with acute deterioration, shunt malfunction, cauda equina syndrome, acute obstructive hydrocephalus, and head and spinal cord trauma. In addition, urgent cases such as non-rapid-onset hydrocephalus, head tumor (the urgency would depend on the history), or problems with recent onset of upper motor neuron symptoms or signs (e.g., cervical or thoracic myelopathy) were included in the elective surgical planning. Pre-operative procedures during the pandemic, including tests to detect COVID-19, are described in the discussion section.
body_text.section: National Institute of Health Research and Development [Badan Penelitian dan Pengembangan

body_text.text: We included data from the previous months to help the reader differentiate the number of surgical procedures before and during the outbreak. Moreover, we compared the type of neurosurgical procedures carried out at our center before and after the announcement of the first COVID-19 case in Yogyakarta. Lastly, we also analyzed the changes in the number of outpatients who visited Dr. Sardjito General Hospital neurosurgical clinic.
body_text.section: National Institute of Health Research and Development [Badan Penelitian dan Pengembangan

body_text.text: The number of confirmed cases in Indonesia had skyrocketed in the last few weeks. By the middle of April, the government had tested more than 30,000 samples (i.e. about 130 tests per 1 million population) and found more than 4,800 confirmed cases, with 459 fatalities ( Figure   4 1). 17, 19 The highest number of death was in the capital city, Jakarta, which had 2,335 infected cases and 241 deaths at the midpoint of April 2020. 20 Moreover, compared to other nations, Indonesia had a considerably higher case fatality rate (i.e., 9.56 %). 19 On the other hand, the mortality rate was rather low, which was roughly one death per 588,000 people. 19
body_text.section: The statistic of COVID-19 in Indonesia

body_text.text: The infection rate in Yogyakarta was not as high as the number that was observed in Jakarta. The first case was detected on March 13, 2020 in a 3-year-old child with a history of a family trip to Depok, West Java. As of April 13, 2020, there were 55 confirmed cases, and six of them died. 18 Sleman, the region where our hospital is located, was the regency with the highest number of positive cases (i.e., 29 cases). Moreover, Yogyakarta has not been declared as the area with local transmission. 21 However, it is strongly suggested that each stakeholder should be vigilant.
body_text.section: COVID-19 in Special Region of Yogyakarta

body_text.text: We divided our experience during this period into four phases to ease the understanding of the
body_text.section: The four phases of the pandemic at Dr. Sardjito Hospital

body_text.text: Our center comprises of six consultant neurosurgeons and 23 residents. We can perform both emergency and elective procedures. 8 In the last nine weeks before the first confirmed case in Indonesia, there was usually an average of four emergency operations each week. However, in early Phase 2, there was a drop in the number of emergency cases to an average of 2.4 surgical procedures per week (Figure 2) . Furthermore, we carried out an average of 16 elective cases during Phase 1 (Figure 2 ). However, in early Phase 2, the number decreased to roughly nine operations each week. This was lower than the average number of elective procedures that were performed in the last nine weeks (i.e. 11 .78 elective surgical procedures in a week). The highest number of operative procedures was the tumor category with 18 cases. On the other hand, trauma surgery had the lowest cases, with only four procedures ( Figure 3 ).
body_text.section: The number of neurosurgical procedures in Dr. Sardjito General Hospital

body_text.text: There was a similar pattern in the number of outpatient visits with the one that we observed in the number of surgical procedures. In the last eight weeks before Phase 1, we had an average of 93.38 outpatients each week ( Figure 4) . However, since early Phase 2, there had been a slight reduction in terms of outpatient numbers, and since March 20, 2020, the decline had become steeper. Furthermore, we had 12 residents who were eligible (based on their year of residency) for providing care in the outpatient clinic. In Phase 1, we allocated 4 -6 residents each day to provide care in the outpatient clinic. However, in the next phase, we reduced the number of residents to just two residents per day due to the reduced number of outpatients.
body_text.section: The number of appointments in Dr. Sardjito General Hospital neurosurgery outpatient clinic

body_text.text: The case of COVID-19 in Indonesia is rather challenging. We have high case-fatality rate yet low mortality rate, which might reflect "the iceberg" phenomenon. Some experts believe that it was associated with Indonesia's low testing rate. 24 Although the number of test had been improved in Phase 2 compared to Phase 1, Indonesia was still among the countries with low testing rate. 25 6 Furthermore, evidence show that there is a high level of SARS-CoV-2 replication in the upper respiratory tract even before the symptoms appear. 26, 27 Consequently, people who are infected with the virus yet do not have any signs or symptoms may possibly spread the virus to others. 28 This issue might cause a significant epidemiological repercussion, especially in countries with low testing rate. 19, 24 In such countries, the asymptomatic persons cannot be widely detected, which in turn might increase the rate of transmission. 29 Therefore, increasing the effort to test as many people as possible might be an essential strategy in reducing the impact of the pandemic. 30
body_text.section: The COVID-19 test in Indonesia: the iceberg phenomenon

body_text.text: In Phase 2, we have started to use screening tests for elective and emergency patients to look for the possibility of COVID-19 infection in the surgical candidate ( Figure 5) . Each test will include the analyses of patient's history (e.g., prior travel, place of living, any closed contact with suspected COVID-19 patient), laboratory test [increased neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) and CRP, decreased lymphocyte count], and chest radiography suggesting COVID-19 infection (i.e., multifocal airspace opacities in the lower lung areas, perihilar and upper lobes abnormalities in the later stage). [31] [32] [33] If the initial tests suggest that the patient was suspected for COVID-19, rapid tests and chest CT-scan can be utilized to establish the diagnosis. The rapid test measures the reactivity of SARS-CoV-2 antibody in patients' blood (i.e. IgG and IgM anti-SARS-CoV-2). For emergency patients, the rapid test can be directly ordered by the neurosurgeons without consulting the case to the COVID-19 team (i.e., the team that is assigned to provide specific management for the suspected COVID-19 patients). If a patient is tested positive by rapid test, one is then sent to undergo an RT-PCR test (i.e. the gold standard for diagnosing COVID-19). 34
body_text.section: Pre-operative preparation in Dr. Sardjito General Hospital during COVID-19 pandemic

body_text.text: Our status as a tertiary referral hospital increases the patient load. 8 We have a long list of patients queueing up to undergo an operative procedure. On some occasions, a tumor patient can even wait for up to six months for having surgery. Consequently, we decided not to eliminate elective surgical procedures during the pandemic. We were aware that the practice was not in line with the recommendation that was published by Indonesian Society of Neurological Surgeons, that 7 suggested a hospital to postpone all elective procedures. 35 We were afraid that such elimination would lengthen patients' waiting period and worsen their condition, which might increase the patient load in the future. Later, it was clear that our policy was aligned with a recommendation from Burke et al 13 that suggested that the elimination of elective surgery was not compulsory until the hospital needs substantial aid from external institutions.
body_text.section: General Hospital

body_text.text: In early Phase 2, however, we reduced the number of elective surgical procedures (Figure 2) . Another substantial issue that affected the number of elective procedures was the low availability of personal protective equipment (PPE) in our hospital. It is recommended that surgeons who are performing an operative procedure for a suspected patient or confirmed cases use level-3 PPE, including N95 mask or equivalent, coverall gown, boots, face shield, and other standard surgical protective gear. 37 Unfortunately, the hospital was struggling to provide proper equipment, especially in the early phase of the outbreak, a problem that also occurred globally. 38 This issue started to improve in the second week of April 2020. The government and related-stakeholders increased the effort to meet the demand. Also, there were supports from non-governmental organization or individuals. An improvement of PPE availability increased the safety aspect of the procedure, which might explain the rise in the number of elective surgical procedures after the second week of April 2020.
body_text.section: General Hospital

body_text.text: As for the emergency cases, the decline could also be seen in early Phase 2 (Figure 2) , which might have partly been caused by the government's "stay at home" recommendation. Such recommendation would possibly cause hesitation among the citizens to leave their home, causing a reduction in the number of traffic accidents, one of the causes of emergency neurosurgery. 36 Lastly, such hesitation might also inhibit one's desire to visit the outpatient clinic, which was then causing a drop in the outpatients in our clinic ( Figure 4) . Consequently, the number of working hours of staff and residents was also reduced.
body_text.section: General Hospital

body_text.text: Based on a WHO guideline, a hospital should build an integrated Hospital Emergency Risk Management Program. The program should contain continuous risk assessment of future threats, multi-hazards early warning system, and emergency simulations to prepare for an outbreak. 39 One example is the creation of clear hospital zoning. By treating different groups of patients in a separate zone, the risk of transmission can be reduced. 39 However, there is no exclusive zone dedicated to treating related patients in our hospital. All COVID-19-clinics and -wards are not located in the same zone. We also treated all surgical patients in the same building in Phase 2 because of limited screening resources. This could result in an increase in transmission if the prevailing procedure resulted in failure to detect positive cases. Furthermore, a good signage system can also be applied to promote physical distancing, hence reduced transmission rate.
body_text.section: The importance of a contingency plan for the next possible pandemic

body_text.text: Therefore, hospital management has to arrange a clear planning for the development of a more appropriate infrastructure to face a future pandemic.
body_text.section: The importance of a contingency plan for the next possible pandemic

body_text.text: COVID-19 brings a deleterious impact to the stability of global public health, including neurosurgical services. Our institution in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, has also been affected by the pandemic, especially in the early phase of the pandemic. Several factors such as the government's slow response, the inadequacy of proper PPE, and low testing rate hindered the management of neurosurgical patients during COVID-19. To help us understand the extent of such impact, we used a four-phase model of the outbreak. In Phase 2, where the first case was detected in Yogyakarta, there was a decline in the number of both emergency and elective surgical procedures. Moreover, the number of outpatients was also diminished. Using this model, we also expected to produce a clear strategy for a better management of neurosurgical patients during the pandemic. Several examples by reducing the number of surgical procedures and advocating the adequate supply of PPE to the stakeholder. In the future, a comprehensive plan can enhance both utilization and safety of the neurosurgical staff.
body_text.section: Conclusion

FIGREF0.text: Moreover, we described Dr. Sardjito General Hospital Division of Neurosurgery policy in performing neurosurgical services during the COVID-19 outbreak and what can be corrected in the future, especially in the setting of LMIC.

FIGREF1.text: nature of the pandemic (Figure 5). Phase 1 (March 2, 2020 -March 13, 2020) was the period of indigency. There were confirmed cases already in Indonesia during this period. However, we had limited knowledge of the disease at the time. As a result, there was no clear diagnosis, and inadequate equipment to manage it. Phase 2 was when the outbreak was detected for the first time in Yogyakarta until the government relax the strict regulation regarding the outbreak. Early in this phase, the number of cases outside Yogyakarta had soared, and the Indonesian Ministry of Health and the Indonesian Medical Association had released several measures as an effort to curb the impact. 22,23 Moreover, Phase 3, the transition phase, is trying to describe the phase where the infection rate has subsided, but the end of the outbreak has not been declared. Lastly, Phase 4 is defined as the period after the outbreak resolved. At the time of this writing, we have not yet entered the last two phases. The inclusion of those two phases is to explain our expectations of the end of the disease.

FIGREF2.text: One of the reasons behind the reduction was the hospital's policy that only allocated two spots in the intensive care unit for post-operative neurosurgical patients. This was meant to prepare for a surge of COVID-19 critical patients. Also, Burke et al 13 recommended a hospital to reduce the number of elective surgery by 25% if there is a total of 10-99 community cases or 7-16 COVID-19 inpatients in the hospital. By the time we reduced the elective procedures, we had 55 cases in Yogyakarta and three COVID-19 inpatients.

back_matter.text: The authors report no conflict of interest concerning the materials or methods used in this study or the findings specified in this paper.
